episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger.

On February 12, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm sent a reminder email to Jerome Hedinger regarding his case. The message, titled “Reminder: Thank you for Choosing The Whaley Law Firm,” was from Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and was addressed to Jerome Hedinger. In the email, Sarena thanked him for the update and information and asked him to complete the documents attached to the DocuSign Notice so that the firm could proceed with his case. She directed that any documents he had should be forwarded directly to her email, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and not as a reply to the DocuSign Notification. For questions, she provided contact options: (502) 583-4022 ext 104 or via email at Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The email included her full signature with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and listed D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104 as contact numbers, along with the note to use the new email address.

Later that same day, around 1:21 PM (times noted with a question mark in the source), Jerome Hedinger replied. He apologized for having gone dark on the matter and explained that the delay was his issue. He stated that he had finally learned the dog owner/tenant’s name—Draylen Round—and that he had obtained records from Baptist and the veterinarian for Rory. He said he would download these records tonight and send them in Word format. He also mentioned receiving a call from the prosecutor who had been handling the day of the case on the day of sentencing. He had not heard back from that prosecutor, but he noted that something had happened to that person. The message was signed by Jerry Hedinger.

Earlier, on February 12, 2024, at around 3:50 AM, Aaron Whaley sent a DocuSign notification to review and sign a document. The message included a header indicating “REVIEW DOCUMENT” and instructed the recipient to “Please complete the attached packet for legal representation for your claims arising out of a Premise Liability incident.” It directed the recipient to contact Aaron Whaley at STuttle.wlf@Gmail.com and to call (502) 583-4022 if there were questions, concluding with “We look forward to working with you.” The email carried the DocuSign branding and warned not to share the email, link, or access code with others. An alternate signing method was provided: visit DocuSign.com, click “Access Documents,” and enter the security code: 4FA7C76180084F9A99902DDA69F96D987. The message explained that it contained a secure link to DocuSign, and included the standard DocuSign boilerplate about electronic signing being safe, secure, and legally binding. It also stated: “Questions about the Document? If you need to modify the document or have questions about the details in the document, please reach out to the sender by emailing them directly.” Additional notes invited the recipient to “Stop receiving this email” or to read more about “Declining to sign” and “Managing notifications,” and offered help via the DocuSign Help Center if signing problems arose. The message encouraged downloading the DocuSign App and closed with a reminder that it was sent by Aaron Whaley using the DocuSign Electronic Signature Service, with the option to request that emails from this sender be stopped.

Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

Re: Reminder: Thank you for Choosing The Whaley Law Firm

This narrative covers the email communications in the Jerome Hedinger premises liability matter. On March 14, 2024 at 11:07 p.m. Eastern Time, Jerome Hedinger wrote to Aaron Whaley, with no CCs listed. In his message, Jerry explained that he had been slow to act, but that his neighbor—who keeps a pit bull and is a convicted felon—received only a light punishment. He stated that the dog is still present and aggressive. He indicated that he has prepared all notes and planned to drop them off, along with the dog owner’s name, phone number, and the prosecutor who allowed the dog to remain. He described an incident from that night in which the pit bull was outside and charged at him again. While expressing that he loves animals, he conveyed a growing fear that the dog could escape again. The message conveyed a desire for prompt, forceful action (“blood now”). He signed the message as Jerry Hedinger and provided his contact number: 502-417-2550.

Earlier, on February 12, 2024, at approximately 1:21 p.m., Jerome Hedinger sent a follow-up note to Aaron Whaley. In this message, he apologized for going dark and attributed the lapse to his own issue. He reported that he had learned the dog owner/tenant’s name, Draylen Round, and that he had obtained records from Baptist and veterinary records for a dog named Rory. He said he would download those records that night and send them in a Word document. He also mentioned receiving a call from the prosecutor who handled the case on the day of sentencing, but that he had never heard back; he suggested that something may have happened to the prosecutor.

Also on February 12, 2024, at 3:50 a.m., Aaron Whaley sent a message via DocuSign to Dr. Hedinger. This message activated an envelope for review and signing, inviting him to complete the attached packet for legal representation regarding his claims arising out of a Premise Liability incident. The message provided contact details for the law firm: (502) 583-4022, and stated that they looked forward to working with him. The DocuSign notification included standard “Envelope Activation” language, a secure link to DocuSign, a “Do Not Share This Email” notice, and an alternate signing method with a security code: 4FA7C76180084F9A99902DDA69F96D987. It explained that the email contains a secure link to DocuSign, and reminded the recipient to contact the sender directly with questions or modifications if needed. The message was authored by Aaron Whaley, whose email address is listed as STuttle.wlf@gmail.com, and it identified the purpose as completing the attached packet for legal representation related to the Premise Liability incident.

Case: Jerome Hedinger, Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger. The matter concerns a new submission from the Whaley Law Firm’s Contact Us channel on May 30, 2024, regarding Mr. Jerome Hedinger’s personal injury claim resulting from a dog bite.

On May 24, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, acting as litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for Mr. Hedinger, emailed Dr. William H. Haney, M.D., to note that the law office represents Mr. Hedinger in a personal injury (dog bite) matter and that a Medical Records & Billing Request had been sent for Mr. Hedinger on March 19, 2024. To date, they had not received a response. The message stated that attempts to contact the Fairfax office or the Nanz Avenue office resulted in the phone displaying “The call did not go through. Please try your call again later.” The communication included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details: (502) 583-4022 Ext 104, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and the firm’s Louisville address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. The message also identified the physician and contact information for follow-up and provided Sarena’s direct line as (502) 357-9971.

On May 30, 2024, at approximately 9:21 AM (the timestamp in the forwarded note shows a question mark next to the time), Dr. Haney’s Office replied, acknowledging the request and apologizing for the late response. The reply stated that Dr. Haney did have the request and would try to obtain it as soon as possible; the writer identified as the Office Manager and noted having many responsibilities, with a commitment to addressing the medical records request the following week. The message was signed by Monica Crume, LPN, Office Manager.

Following that, on May 30, 2024, at 9:45 AM, Sarena Tuttle responded with a formal note reiterating the issues. She thanked Dr. Haney’s office for the response and explained that the client had suffered an injury and was awaiting compensation. She emphasized that, in Kentucky, any medical provider is required to respond to and fulfill patient-record requests within 30 days, and noted that this request was over 60 days old and was delaying Mr. Hedinger’s claim. She urged the records and bills to be forwarded as soon as possible and provided contact options: (502) 583-4022, Ext 104, or Bryce at Ext 114. The message closed with Sarena’s contact details, including The Whaley Law Firm’s address, direct line (502) 357-9971, office line (502) 583-4022 Ext 104, and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with a postscript stating “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

This file concerns Jerome Hedinger (Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023). The matter is titled “Re: New submission from Contact Us,” and it centers on a dog-bite personal injury claim. The chain begins with notices that the Whaley Law Firm had requested medical records for Mr. Hedinger and had not received responses, with additional concerns about accessibility to records from the Fairfax office and the Nanz Ave office.

On May 24, 2024, at 11:43 AM, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm wrote that their office represents Mr. Jerome Hedinger for a personal injury (dog bite) and that, on March 19, 2024, they mailed in a Medical Records & Billing Request for Mr. Hedinger. To date, they had not received a response, and every attempt to call the Fairfax office or the Nanz Ave office resulted in the phone message “The call did not go through. Please try your call again later.” The message requested that someone from Records & Billing contact them to discuss the matter. The communication included the firm’s contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new email address).

Later, on May 30, 2024, the thread shows several responses. At 9:21 AM, Dr. Haney Office wrote: “Hi! Sorry for the late reply. I do have the request and I will try to get it as soon as I Can. I am the Office manager and have many responsibilities and request for medical records. I will try to get to this next week. Sorry for any inconvenience.” The message was signed by Monica Crume, LPN, Office Manager.

At 9:45 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied: “Thank you for the response. While we do understand people have many, many responsibilities, our client has suffered an injury and is awaiting compensation. Without these records we are unable to move forward in the recovery for our client. As a medical office manager, you should be aware that any medical provider in the state of Kentucky is required to respond and fulfill any and all record requests within 30 days. This request is over 60 days old and is delaying the claim of our client. Please forward these records and bills as soon as possible. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly at (502) 583-4022 ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114.”

Shortly after, at 11:13 AM, Dr. Haney Office wrote: “Hi Sarena I just left you a message on your VM. I am looking at his chart and we have never seen the patient for any dog bites, nor do we have any records from any ER/UC that he was seen. Please call me when you get a chance to discuss.” This message was signed by Monica Crume, LPN, Office Manager.

At 11:40 AM, Monica Crume followed up with: “Senera, I decided to look into the Baptist system and I found this report. So I thought I would send it to you since you were having issues getting it. I will have the letter to you today once completed. Thank you.”

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

Re: New submission from Contact Us

In this matter, the Whaley Law Firm represents Mr. Jerome Hedinger in a personal injury (dog bite) case. On May 24, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Dr. William H. Haney, M.D., at his office. The message stated that their office had previously submitted a Medical Records & Billing Request for Mr. Hedinger on March 19, 2024 and had not yet received a response. It noted that attempts to reach the Fairfax office or the Nanz Avenue office had resulted in phones that "state[d] 'The call did not go through. Please try your call again later.'" Sarena asked that someone from the Records & Billing Department contact them to discuss the matter. Her contact details were provided: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (with a note indicating a new email address). The message also listed the firm’s name, Sarena’s role, and the physician involved, highlighting that the office represents Mr. Hedinger for the dog bite personal injury.

Subsequently, Dr. Haney’s office replied in a series of messages. On May 30, 2024, at 9:21 AM, Dr. Haney wrote that he was sorry for the late reply and that he did have the request, but as the office manager he had many responsibilities and requests for medical records. He said he would try to get to the request next week and apologized for any inconvenience. Monica Crume, LPN, Office Manager, signed the message and provided contact information: 502-897-6568.

Later that same morning, at 9:45 AM, Sarena responded again, emphasizing that while they understood people have many responsibilities, their client had been injured and was awaiting compensation. She pointed out that without the records they could not move forward with the recovery for Mr. Hedinger. She reminded Dr. Haney that, in Kentucky, medical providers are required to respond to and fulfill record requests within 30 days, and noted that this request was over 60 days old and delaying the claim. She requested the records and bills be forwarded promptly and provided direct contact details for follow-up: (502) 583-4022 ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114, and re-stated her email address.

Earlier that morning, at 11:13 AM, Dr. Haney sent another message noting that he had left Sarena a voicemail and that he was reviewing Hedinger’s chart. He stated that they had never seen Mr. Hedinger for any dog bites and did not have any records from any ER/urgent care indicating such treatment. He asked Sarena to call him when she had a chance to discuss the matter further. His message was signed by Monica Crume, LPN, Office Manager, with contact information: 502-897-6568.

Shortly after, at 11:40 AM, another message from Dr. Haney stated, “Senera, I decided to look into the Baptist system and I found this report. So I thought I would send it to you since you were having issues getting it. I will have the letter to you today once completed. Thank you.” This message was also attributed to Monica Crume.

Finally, at 12:14 PM on May 30, 2024, the Dr. Haney Office sent a closing note to Sarena: “Sarena, See if this will work for you. you’re welcome!!” The thread is titled “Re: New submission from Contact Us” and originates from Dr. Haney Office (haneyoffice@ultmd.com) to Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com).

In summary, the file documents a dog-bite personal injury case for Jerome Hedinger, with The Whaley Law Firm requesting Mr. Hedinger’s medical records and bills first submitted on March 19, 2024. The communications reveal persistent delays and a lack of response from the Fairfax and Nanz Avenue offices, repeated assurances from Dr. Haney’s team about locating or obtaining the records (including a search of the Baptist system), and reminders about Kentucky’s 30-day record-response requirements, noting that the request had exceeded 60 days without fulfillment. The chain concludes with a courtesy confirmation from Dr. Haney’s office indicating that the materials or letter were being pursued for delivery.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger. Re: 8911611948 Hedinger Aetna Bill.

The communications involve Jerome Hedinger and The Whaley Law Firm regarding a demand related to an Aetna bill in a case that appears to be tracked under the Jerome Hedinger premises file. On June 19, 2024, Jerome emailed Sarena Tuttle asking what had been requested on the demand notice, inquiring, “Hey Sarena, what did we ask for on the demand notice? Just curious.”

Looking back through the chain, on June 13, 2024, at approximately 3:46 PM, Jerome Hedinger replied to Sarena with a “Thanks Sarena!” Sarena had earlier that day indicated they had received the Certified Medical Records and Billing from Baptist Health, and that Bryce was applying the final touches to the demand and that it should go out that day or first thing the next morning. She explained that once the Demand is sent, the at-fault insurer would have 30-45 days to review the information and provide a response, though the Adjuster could respond at any time, and they would update Jerome as soon as they heard back to discuss the response in detail. Sarena also invited Jerome to contact them directly with any questions. Her signature notes she is a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and contact details, and an indication to note her new email address at Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Earlier on June 13, 2024, at 3:28 AM, Jerome had asked Sarena for progress on the Demand Draft and whether anything else was needed. Then on June 13, 2024, at 9:56 AM, Sarena reiterated the update about receiving the medical records and billing, Bryce working on the final demand, and the expected timing for sending the demand, along with the 30- to 45-day review period by the at-fault insurer and the possibility of an earlier response by the Adjuster, adding that they would keep Jerome updated and inviting any questions.

The thread also shows ongoing coordination in late May. On May 30, 2024, at 1:39 PM, Jerome wrote to Sarena asking if the attached material from Aetna would help. Sarena responded later that day (2:16 PM), thanking him and saying she had also received photos of the fence, which would be helpful. She stated she would forward everything to Aaron and Bryce and hoped to get a Demand out by the end of the next week. Later that same day, on May 30 at 4:28 PM, Jerome asked whether Rory’s vet bills had been obtained. In response, Sarena confirmed the request and noted that she had received Rory’s vet bills and the fence photos, that she would forward everything to Aaron and Bryce, and that she aimed to have a Demand drafted by the end of the following week. The following day, May 31, 2024, at 9:44 AM, Sarena wrote that she had received the materials toward the end of the previous day and had sent everything to Bryce to draft the Demand, promising to update Jerome as soon as the Demand went out.

In summary, the case chronology shows Jerome Hedinger communicating with Sarena Tuttle about compiling and drafting a demand related to the 8911611948 Hedinger Aetna Bill, with material being gathered from Aetna and Baptist Health (as well as associated vet bills and fence photos), tasks delegated to Bryce and Aaron for drafting, and a planned timeline indicating the Demand would be sent within days of mid-June 2024, with the at-fault insurer given 30-45 days to respond, and the team committing to keep Jerome updated throughout the process.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome Hedinger – Hedinger Aetna Bill (8911611948)  
Client: Jerome Hedinger

In late May 2024, the Whaley Law Firm began coordinating the preparation of a demand related to an Aetna bill for Jerome Hedinger. Sarena Tuttle, the firm’s litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, asked Bryce to draft the demand after receiving Rory’s veterinary bills and photos of a fence, which Jerome had provided. On May 30, 2024 at 1:39 PM, Jerome asked Sarena if the materials “this is from Aetna” would help her. The following message at 2:16 PM confirmed: “Thank you so much Jerry, This is perfect. I did also receive the photos of the fence which will be helpful as well. I will get all of this over to Aaron & Bryce right now and hopefully get a Demand out by the end of the next week.” Later that afternoon, at 4:28 PM, Jerome followed up asking, “Did we get you Rory’s vet bills?”

By May 31, 2024 at 9:44 AM, Sarena replied that she had received the items the previous day toward the end of the day and had sent everything to Bryce to have the Demand drafted, promising to update Jerome as soon as it went out.

The process continued into June. On June 13, 2024 at 3:28 AM, Jerome checked in again, asking, “Hi Sarena, just checking in on the progress for the Demand Draft. Do you need anything else?” Later that day, at 9:56 AM, Sarena reported that they had received Certified Medical Records and Billing from Baptist Health and that Bryce was finishing the demand, which should go out that day or first thing the next day. She noted that once the Demand is sent, the at-fault insurer would have 30-45 days to review the information and provide a response, though the Adjuster could respond at any time; they would update Jerome as soon as any response was received and would discuss it in detail. She also encouraged Jerome to contact them with any questions.

On Monday, June 24, 2024 at about 12:30 PM, Sarena apologized for being out of the office the prior week due to a cremation ceremony and said she would check with Bryce about the Demand value and that one of them would reach out as soon as possible.

Finally, on Wednesday, June 26, 2024 at 11:43 AM, Sarena sent an update to Jerome: Bryce had advised that the Demand Amount was $25,000.00. She reminded Jerome that the Demand Amount is merely a starting point for negotiations and that the Adjuster would have 30-45 days to respond, with the expectation of a lowball offer at first as part of standard negotiation strategy. She also noted that Bryce or Aaron would contact him as soon as a response was received to discuss the negotiation process in more detail, and she encouraged him to reach out with any questions.

Signature details included Sarena M. Tuttle’s role as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and contact numbers (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104) and her new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com). The chain of communications shows ongoing collection of medical records, billing, and additional supporting documents, the drafting and issuance of the Demand, and the expected negotiation process with the insurer.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome Hedinger – Premises (Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023). Client: Jerome Hedinger. This matter concerns the Aetna medical bill identified as 8911611948 Hedinger Aetna Bill.

On May 30, 2024, Jerome Hedinger sent an email to Sarena Tuttle asking, “Sarena this is from Aetna. Does this help you?” Later that same day, Sarena replied that the materials from Aetna were “perfect” and that she had also received photos of the fence, which would be helpful. She stated that she would forward everything to Bryce and Aaron so they could draft the Demand, with the hope that it would be sent by the end of the next week. In the afternoon, Jerome followed up asking, “Did we get Rory’s vet bills?”

The following day, May 31, 2024, Sarena confirmed that the documents were received the previous day “toward the end of the day” and had been sent to Bryce to draft the Demand, adding that she would update Jerome as soon as the Demand went out.

Several weeks later, on June 13, 2024, Jerome checked in again, asking, “Hi Sarena, just checking in on the progress for the Demand Draft. Do you need anything else?” Later that morning, Sarena responded that they had finally received the Certified Medical Records and Billing from Baptist Health, and that Bryce was putting the final touches on the Demand. She indicated that the Demand should go out that day or first thing the next day. She also explained that once the Demand is sent, the at-fault insurer would have 30-45 days to review the information and respond, though the Adjuster could respond at any time. She offered to discuss the process further and encouraged Jerome to reach out with any questions. Her contact details at The Whaley Law Firm were provided, including the new email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and the firm’s Louisville address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104.

On June 19, 2024, Jerome again asked Sarena, “What did we ask for on the demand notice? Just curious.” On June 24, 2024, Sarena apologized for being out of the office the prior week due to a cremation ceremony and said she would check with Bryce about the Demand value and would have someone reach out as soon as possible.

Then, on June 26, 2024, Sarena informed Jerome that Bryce advised the Demand Amount was $25,000.00. She reminded him that the Demand Amount is only a starting point for negotiations and that the insurer would have 30-45 days to respond, anticipating a low initial offer as a normal negotiation tactic. She added that Bryce or Aaron would contact him as soon as a response was received and would discuss the negotiation process in more detail. Jerome replied to Sarena’s message with a thank-you.

Throughout these communications, the parties referenced Bryce and Aaron as points of contact for negotiation and progress; the communications consistently noted timelines (30-45 days for insurer responses; initial offers typically low), the collection and transmission of medical records and related documents (Baptist Health records, other medical records, and Rory’s vet bills), and supporting materials (photos of the fence). The firm’s communications also reiterated the updated contact information for Sarena and the firm’s address and phone numbers.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Jerome Hedinger – Premise (Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023). Client: Jerome Hedinger.

On July 23, 2024, a correspondence chain concerning claim 17N8360G8 was opened between The Whaley Law Firm and State Farm Fire & Casualty. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Jessica L. Paolini of State Farm, forwarding a demand related to the 17N8360G8 matter. In Bryce’s email, which was addressed to Jessica Paolini and copied to Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine project email address (JeromeHedingerZ4403793@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), he noted that the attached demand was being provided and asked Jessica to review it and advise if there were any questions. Bryce’s message also included his firm’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., and included a standard attorney-client disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged or protected information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, refrain from using or forwarding the information, and understand that no waiver of privilege shall apply.

Earlier in the same chain, Jessica Paolini had replied to Bryce at 9:56 AM, indicating that Bryce could forward the demand to the email address above (the State Farm address). This set the stage for Bryce to forward the demand the next morning.

Later that morning, at 10:09 AM, Bryce sent a follow-up email with the subject line [EXTERNAL] Re: 17N8360G8, attaching the demand. In this message, Bryce again addressed Jessica and copied Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine project email address. He thanked Jessica and invited any questions regarding the matter. The communication included Bryce’s signature block with his name, firm, and contact details, and carried the same confidentiality disclaimer that the prior message contained.

At 10:35 AM, Jessica Paolini replied to Bryce, stating that she had received the demand and would reach out to him shortly. In her reply, she included her direct line (610-358-8405), toll-free line (844-458-4300, ext 6103588405), fax number (844-236-3646), and State Farm’s email address for claims (statefarmfireclaims@statefarm.com) along with a note to have only the claim number in the subject line. She also reminded Bryce not to miss calls from State Farm and suggested adding State Farm to his contacts by texting HOME to 62789. Her message also contained the standard State Farm correspondence format and her identifying title as a State Farm Claim Specialist.

Together, the sequence shows the request for the 17N8360G8 demand was initially sent by The Whaley Law Firm to State Farm with the intent that Jessica Paolini would handle the claim, and that Jessica subsequently acknowledged receipt of the demand and committed to following up, while providing her direct contact channels and instructions regarding email subject content. The chain also confirms that Jerome Hedinger’s file was included in the communications via the Filevine project email address.

__Important Follow Up__
From: Jerome Hedinger [jlhedinger@gmail.com](mailto:jlhedinger@gmail.com)
To: sarena@whaleylawfirm.com 
CC: 
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2024 10:33:50 -0400

Hey Serena, I wanted to make you guys aware of some stuff attached to my dog bite case. On Saturday I was around a couple of pit bulls at Cherokee Park and it triggered a full blown panic attack. I genuinely wanted to runs I went to sit in the car to get my breathing together to calm down. I’m not trying to be a wimp here but clearly the anxiety I’ve had since the attack has been getting worse. I made an appointment with a therapist who specializes in PTSD. But this is now affecting my daily interactions. At this point should I send in a paper from the psychiatrist? 

Finally have we heard anything back from the other side yet?

Thanks!
Jerry Hedinger
502-417-2559

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger.

This note records a sequence of communications regarding Jerome Hedinger’s case, beginning with a forward email titled “Checking In.” On Friday, September 13, 2024 at 2:19 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, forwarded the message to Bryce Koon. In that forwarded note, she wrote that Jerry Hedinger is specifically requesting that Bryce give him a call. The forward includes Sarena’s firm contact details and notes a new email address for contact: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The Whaley Law Firm’s address is 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line 502-357-9971 and office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104.

The forwarded chain begins with a message from Jerome Hedinger dated September 13, 2024, at approximately 1:58 PM, addressed to Sarena. In this message, Jerry asks that Bryce be called and states he is free all day; he wants to understand where the case stands and to receive an update on the process, and he notes that late afternoon would be perfectly fine. He provides his contact number as 502-417-2550 and signs as Jerry Hedinger.

Earlier that same day, at about 10:48 AM, Sarena replied to Jerry. She wrote that there is no need to worry and that Bryce will reach out to discuss any offers made, noting that she did not believe any offers had been made yet. She also signaled her availability and provided her firm contact details and the new email address.

Earlier communications in the week show ongoing back-and-forth. On Thursday, September 12, 2024, at 4:59 PM, Jerry Hedinger wrote to Sarena: “Sarena, didn’t mean to confuse anyone. I’m a bit loopy today’s, sorry for the typos. I was saying I only spoke to you via email.” 

That same day, at 12:22 PM, Sarena wrote: “ I do not know if he actually spoke with her, that is why I have to check in with him. Our Files document any and all calls, so I can see he called, but I do not have any notes as to the details at the moment.” Her signature followed.

At 12:04 PM, Jerry wrote: “Did spoke to anyone, just left you a message.” Sarena again responded at 12:00 PM, writing: “Good morning Jerry, I’m so sorry to hear that. I hope you are feeling better now. Your claim is over with Bryce for negotiations, let me check in with him and see where we are at. I know he attempted to speak with your adjuster yesterday but I was not a party to the conversation.” 

Earlier still, on Wednesday, September 11, 2024 at 11:14 AM, Jerome Hedinger wrote: “Hi Sabrina, just checking on where we are with my case. I had a literal heart attack last week and I’m trying to make sure loose ends are moving in the right direction.” He signed as Jerry Hedinger and provided the contact number 502-417-2550.

In summary, the record shows Jerry Hedinger, the client in the Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB case, has been trying to obtain an update on the status of his claim. He indicated a recent heart event (a heart attack) and expressed a desire to ensure that loose ends are being addressed. The firm’s staff have communicated that Bryce will contact him regarding any offers (if any have been made) and have noted that, as of the latest messages, no offers had been reported. The communications involve multiple back-and-forths between Jerry and Sarena Tuttle, with Bryce Koon as the designated contact for negotiation updates, and reference to the involvement of Jerry’s adjuster. All messages include the dates and approximate times listed above and reflect the contact information for Jerry and the Whaley Law Firm.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger. Re: Checking In.

On September 11, 2024 at 11:14 a.m., Jerome Hedinger wrote to Sabrina (Sarena) expressing concern about the status of his case and noting he had a heart attack the prior week; he asked that loose ends be moved in the right direction and stated he was trying to understand where things stood. The message began, “Hi Sabrina, just checking on where we are with my case. I had a literal heart attack last week and I’m trying to make sure loose ends are moving in the right direction.”

On September 12, 2024 at 12:00 p.m., Sarena Tuttle responded: “Good morning Jerry, No worries. I completely understand. Bryce will reach out to discuss any offers made, I did not believe they have made any offers just yet.” She noted that Bryce handles negotiations and that she would check in with him, adding that he had attempted to speak with Jerry’s adjuster the day before, though she was not a party to that conversation. Sarena signed as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and contact information, and a reminder to note the new email address.

At 12:04 p.m. on September 12, Jerome replied, “Did speak to anyone, just left you a message.”

At 12:22 p.m. on September 12, Sarena replied, or noted, that she did not know whether Jerome had spoken with “her” (likely the adjuster), and explained that she needed to check with Bryce. She added that their files document all calls, but she did not have notes detailing the conversation at that moment.

At 4:59 p.m. on September 12, Jerome wrote again, “Did speak to anyone, just left you a message.” He indicated there may have been some confusion and apologized for typos, reiterating that he had spoken to no one beyond leaving messages for Sarena.

On September 13, 2024 at 10:48 a.m., Sarena wrote: “Good morning Jerry, No worries. I completely understand. Bryce will reach out to discuss any offers made; I did not believe they have made any offers just yet.” This confirmed that, as of that morning, no offers had been made.

At 1:58 p.m. on September 13, 2024, Jerome replied: “Serena please have Bryce call, I’m free all day. I just want to understand where we are and get an update on the process. Late afternoon is perfectly fine.” He provided the contact number 502-417-2550 and reinforced his availability for an update.

Finally, at 2:20 p.m. on September 13, 2024, Sarena sent a final note to Jerome: “Good afternoon Jerry, I have sent your email over to him & requested he give you a call.” This indicates Bryce was being contacted to call Jerome for an update.

Sarena M. Tuttle’s signature appears with her title and the firm’s contact details:
Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)

This sequence reflects ongoing coordination between Jerome Hedinger and The Whaley Law Firm, with Bryce as the designated negotiations contact, and a pending update on offers as of mid-September 2024.

episodes.natural_language:
This file documents a series of checking-in communications in September 2024 between the client, Jerome Hedinger, and The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager), regarding Jerome Hedinger’s case, labeled Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. The exchanges involve coordinating with Bryce for negotiations, updates on offers, and confirming who has spoken with Jerome’s adjuster.

The first dated message in the thread is from September 11, 2024, at about 11:14 AM. Jerome Hedinger wrote to Sabrina (Sarena’s colleague or an earlier recipient in the thread): “Hi Sabrina, just checking on where we are with my case. I had a literal heart attack last week and I’m trying to make sure loose ends are moving in the right direction.” He included his phone number, 502-417-2550, and signed as Jerry Hedinger.

On September 12, 2024, at around 12:00 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied: “Good morning Jerry, I’m so sorry to hear that. Your claim is over with Bryce for negotiations, let me check in with him and see where we are at. I know he attempted to speak with your adjuster yesterday but I was not a party to the conversation.” Her signature block provides The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information, including 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and notes a new email address.

Jerome responded shortly after, around 12:04 PM, stating: “Did speak to anyone, just left you a message.” He again signed as Jerry Hedinger.

At approximately 12:22 PM, Sarena replied: “?? - I do not know if he actually spoke with her, that is why I have to check in with him. Our Files document any and all calls, so I can see he called, but I do not have any notes as to the details at the moment.” This indicates she was trying to verify whether Jerome’s interaction occurred and notes that the firm’s files track all calls.

Later the same day, about 4:59 PM, Jerome wrote again: “Sarena, didn’t mean to confuse anyone. I’m a bit loopy today’s, sorry for the typos. I was saying I only spoke to you via email.” This note clarifies that he intended to indicate he had only communicated with Sarena via email, not by phone.

The following day, September 13, 2024, around 10:48 AM, Sarena wrote again: “Good morning Jerry, No worries. I completely understand. Bryce will reach out to discuss any offers made, I did not believe they have made any offers just yet.” She also provided her contact details and reminded that Bryce is the point of contact for negotiations and any offers.

That same day, September 13, 2024, at about 1:58 PM, Jerome replied: “Sarena please have Bryce call, I’m free all day. I just want to understand where we are and get an update on the process. Late afternoon is perfectly fine.” He included his number again, 502-417-2550, and signed as Jerry Hedinger.

Additional details in the chain include Sarena’s signature with the firm’s information and a note to pay attention to her new email address. The communications reference Bryce as the negotiator and discuss whether offers have been made, with Sarena indicating that no offers were believed to have been made yet. The overall intent of the exchanges is to obtain an update on the case status, confirm who has spoken to Jerome’s adjuster, and coordinate a call with Bryce for a potential negotiation update.

Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Spoke to client. Explained where we are with dog bite and necessity of filing - he understood. He is going to send us over some notes and information from his therapist about recent troubles with dogs and PTSD. 

Also talked to him about his heart. Its a much trickier situation, but from my understanding it goes like this:
- Client had aortic valve replacement in 2010 and has mechanical value - has been taking blood thinners since (Warfarin)
- Client's gastro told him to stop taking blood thinners because of colonoscopy
- Gastro did not communicate with Cardio doctor about taking off blood thinners
- About two weeks later, client gets a clot and has a heart attack
- Doctor put in stent and told him that it was because he was off heart meds
- Client doesn't think doctors actually signed off on him going off blood thinners
- Now has to go through months of cardio rehab and has heart damage (decreased ejection fraction of left ventricle - shown by echo)

I told him I would request the records from the doctors and try to look into in. In the meantime I am going to be filing his suit. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Bryce
__Date & Time__: September 26 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Initial client contact on September 26, 2024 with Jerome Hedinger regarding the dog bite case and the necessity of filing; this contact was made by Bryce. I explained where we are with the dog bite matter and the need to file, and he understood. He said he would send over notes and information from his therapist about recent troubles with dogs and PTSD.

We also discussed his heart, which is a much trickier situation. He had an aortic valve replacement in 2010 with a mechanical valve and has been taking blood thinners (Warfarin) since then. His gastroenterologist told him to stop taking the blood thinners because of a colonoscopy, but the gastro did not communicate with his cardiology doctor about stopping the anticoagulation. About two weeks after stopping, he developed a clot and had a heart attack. A stent was placed, and the doctors told him that it was because he had been off his heart medications. He does not think the doctors actually signed off on him stopping the blood thinners. He now has to undergo months of cardio rehab and has heart damage, specifically a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction, as shown by an echocardiogram.

I told him I would request the records from the treating doctors and look into this. In the meantime, I am going to file his suit.

__Dog Bite Suit?__
From: Jerome Hedinger [jlhedinger@gmail.com](mailto:jlhedinger@gmail.com)
To: Sarena Tuttle [Sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:Sarena@whaleylawfirm.com), Aaron Whaley [Agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:Agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)

Date: Thu, 3 Oct 2024 17:57:06 -0500

Aaron, hey we are bumping up on the one year date or the pitbull attack. Do we have a plan to file this before October 11? Got a week to go and I just want to know where we stand. The second thing nobody has mentioned is the major screw up between Dr Lazlo Maak and Dr Jeff Stidam’s blood thinner clinic. I threw a clot and I’m seriously facing a genuinely uncertain future because a nurse didn’t do her job. Feel free to call anytime.

Jerry Hedinger
502-417-2550

episodes.original_body:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Email:
Sabrina we are bumping up on the one year anniversary of the dog attack. I want to make certain I don’t miss out because we miss a deadline to file. Can you please have who’s handling my case call me to discuss options?

Replied to Client:
Good afternoon Jerry,
 I greatly apologize for the delayed response. Bryce filed your Premise Liability (Dog Bite) Complaint on September 27, 2024 in the Jefferson County Circuit Court. At this time, we have to await service of the Defendant. Once the Defendant is served, we will move into a 'Discovery' phase, which we will discuss in further detail once we move into that phase. In the meantime, there is nothing further for you to do at this time. As far as your case regarding the issue between your physicians, Bryce is reviewing that claim and should be reaching out to discuss that with you in further detail. I do know I have a list of medical records he has asked me to request related to that claim, if we need additional information on that claim, Bryce will reach out to you. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: October 07 2024

Initial client contact occurred on October 24, 2023, when the client emailed Sabrina noting that they are approaching the one-year anniversary of the dog attack and expressing concern about missing a filing deadline. The client asked that the person handling the case call him to discuss options.

Replied to the client on October 7, 2024. Sarena was the person making contact. In the message, she apologized for the delayed response and explained that Bryce filed the Premise Liability (Dog Bite) Complaint on September 27, 2024 in the Jefferson County Circuit Court. At that time, the case must await service of the Defendant. Once service is effected, the matter will move into a Discovery phase, which will be discussed in detail once that phase begins. In the meantime, there is nothing further for the client to do. Regarding the issue between the client’s physicians, Bryce is reviewing that claim and should reach out to discuss it in more detail. Sarena noted she has a list of medical records Bryce has asked her to request related to that claim, and Bryce will contact the client if additional information is needed. If the client has any questions, they are advised to contact the firm directly.

Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Client Executed Verification Forms & DC Auths - Client also replied to Text with Updated Address - 10008 Smock Mill Lane, (Temple, Tx 76502) - Client asked why DC wants Tax Authorization & why do they need medical authorization when they have the medical records 

Replied to Client via Text:

 Good morning Jerry,
Thank you for the updated address. Is that Temple, TX 76502? As far as your questions, the Defendant will not have access to this information, only his attorney. Tax Info is requested when there are lost wages or a diminished capacity to labor and/or earn. We will likely object to this request and not provide the authorization, however, that is up to the attorneys to formally decide. In regard to the medical records, the Defense has the right to verify to information provided by requesting their own copy of the records so they can maintain their own chain of evidence. Also, they would be looking for any pre-existing conditions to minimize the damages sought. We understand that neither of these situations fit your specific case, however, Discovery is a standardized phase of litigation and certain information is requested as a 'standard practice'. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: October 23 2024
episodes.natural_language:

The client, Jerome Hedinger, had executed verification forms and DC authorizations and replied by text with an updated address: 10008 Smock Mill Lane, Temple, TX 76502. He also asked why the defense counsel wants Tax Authorization and why medical authorization is needed when he already has the medical records.

The reply to the client via text, from Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm, dated October 23, 2024, stated: 
"Good morning Jerry,
Thank you for the updated address. Is that Temple, TX 76502? As far as your questions, the Defendant will not have access to this information, only his attorney. Tax Info is requested when there are lost wages or a diminished capacity to labor and/or earn. We will likely object to this request and not provide the authorization, however, that is up to the attorneys to formally decide. In regard to the medical records, the Defense has the right to verify to information provided by requesting their own copy of the records so they can maintain their own chain of evidence. Also, they would be looking for any pre-existing conditions to minimize the damages sought. We understand that neither of these situations fit your specific case, however, Discovery is a standardized phase of litigation and certain information is requested as a 'standard practice'. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm" The communication was made by Sarena.

Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Order Granting MTA - Added Renter/Sister Jessica Burden to Complaint - Sent Client Text w/Upd

Good morning Jerry,
We just wanted to update you that the Defense Attorney for 432 Atwood, the property owners, have named their Renter & Mr. Brown's Sister in their response to your Complaint & filed a cross complaint against Mrs. Burden & Mr. Brown as well. We are currently awaiting Mrs. Burden to be served before moving forward with additional discovery requests. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me or Bryce directly to discuss them in further detail at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. - Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: October 29 2024
episodes.natural_language:
On October 29, 2024, Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm made initial contact with client Jerome Hedinger after the firm had received an Order Granting MTA. The record notes that Jessica Burden, identified as the renter and Mr. Brown's sister, was added to the complaint, and that a text with this update was sent to the client.

In the client update text, Sarena advised that the defense attorney for the property owners at 432 Atwood had named their renter and Mr. Brown's sister in their response to the complaint and had filed a cross-complaint against Mrs. Burden and Mr. Brown as well. The team is currently awaiting service of Mrs. Burden before moving forward with additional discovery requests. If the client has any questions, they were instructed to contact Sarena or Bryce directly to discuss in further detail at (502) 583-4022, Ext. 104 for Sarena or Ext. 114 for Bryce. Signed by Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm. Person Making Contact: Sarena. Date & Time: October 29, 2024.

Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger. This note concerns the matter Hedinger v. Atwood and documents an exchange from January 14, 2025 among the Whaley Law Firm team and opposing counsel.

Early in the day on January 14, 2025, Bryce Koon of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Aaron Whaley with Sarena Tuttle copied on the message. In his note, Bryce wrote, “Not sure how but I guess I completely missed these. I will get responses out this week.” The email header shows the message was sent at 15:24:06 in the eastern time zone. The message also indicates there was an ensuing reply from Aaron Whaley around 3:18 PM, though the content of that reply is not included in the excerpt.

Earlier that same day, a separate email was forwarded from David T. Klapheke of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP to Aaron Whaley, with Paige Hornback CC’d. The forwarded message is dated Tuesday, January 14, 2025, at 2:54 PM (time shown as 2:54?PM in the excerpt) and bears the subject Hedinger v. Atwood. In it, Klapheke addresses Aaron directly, beginning with “Aaron: Hope you are doing well.” He states that discovery requests in the Hedinger v. Atwood case were served on October 22, 2024, but no responses have been received. He then asks that Whaley Law Firm provide their responses within two weeks and notes that this is an effort under the local rules to address a discovery dispute before filing a motion to compel. The message is signed with the standard professional contact details for David T. Klapheke:

- Partner, Dinsmore & Shohl LLP • Legal Counsel
- 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202
- T (502) 540-2539 • F (502) 585-2207
- E David.Klapheke@Dinsmore.com • dinsmore.com

The forwarded email includes a notice typical of attorney-client communications, warning that the transmission may constitute privileged attorney-client material and is not intended for unauthorized recipients. It instructs recipients who may have received the message in error to delete it and notify the sender so the address records can be corrected. The message also shows the recipient as agwhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com and CC’d Paige Hornback, with the Dinsmore logo appearing in the body of the email.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

Spoke to adjuster. The insurance company we have is the home owner, not the renter/dog owner. They are trying to get a copy of the lease, presumably to try and find a way out of liability. We never got anything back from the dog owner about rental insurance, so its unclear if there is any available. I told the adjuster that if we don't have a response to the demand by next week I will be forced to file this one due to upcoming SOL.
episodes.natural_language:
On October 24, 2023, in the Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023 file, I spoke with the adjuster regarding client Jerome Hedinger. The insurer on record is the homeowner’s policy, not the renter/dog owner. The adjuster is attempting to obtain a copy of the lease, presumably to identify a way out of liability.

We have not received any response from the dog owner regarding rental insurance, so it is unclear whether rental insurance is available. I informed the adjuster that if we do not receive a response to the demand by next week, I will be forced to file this case due to the upcoming SOL (statute of limitations).
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

Reviewing activity in Jerome Hedinger Premise (DB) 10/24/2023 between 12/25/2024 and 1/24/2025...

This case involves Jerome Hedinger suing Dahlyn Brown and others, likely related to a dog attack incident where Hedinger and his dog were injured by a pitbull while on a walk.
The most recent activity shows that discovery responses were served to the opposing counsel on January 20, 2025, including a Dropbox link for document production. (See details)
A potential red flag is that the plaintiff's team missed the initial deadline for discovery responses, which were due on October 22, 2024. This led to a warning from opposing counsel about a potential motion to compel. (See details), (See details)

episodes.natural_language:
The Jerome Hedinger Premise case (DB), docketed as Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023, concerns a claim by Jerome Hedinger against Dahlyn Brown and others, likely arising from a dog-attack incident in which Hedinger and his dog were injured by a pit bull while on a walk. The activity being reviewed covers the period from December 25, 2024, to January 24, 2025, for a case dating back to 10/24/2023.

The most recent activity shows that discovery responses were served to the opposing counsel on January 20, 2025, and these responses included a Dropbox link for document production. A potential red flag is that the plaintiff’s team missed the initial discovery deadline, which was due on October 22, 2024, leading to a warning from opposing counsel about a potential motion to compel.

The next steps should be to confirm that all defendants have been properly served and to monitor for responses to the recently submitted discovery. Additionally, the team should gather any available photographic evidence of injuries, as none were found in the current records.

If you have any questions in this regard, please let me know.” The email identified The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone and fax numbers as provided, and included the standard attorney‑client disclaimer asserting that the message may contain privileged information and should not be shared if received in error; it directed the recipient to contact The Whaley Law Firm if the message was received in error and stated that no privilege is waived by disclosure to the named recipient. The email was sent with CCs to Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 – Filevine Project Email Address (JeromeHedingerZ4403793@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) and to Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com). The message also carried a separate “NOTICE” clarifying that the transmission from Dinsmore & Shohl may constitute an attorney‑client communication privileged at law, and that if received in error, the recipient should delete it and notify the sender to correct the address record.

Later on February 17, 2025, at 12:59 PM (approximately), Paige E. Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl replied: “Bryce, Received. Thanks for forwarding. Paige.” This reply is shown as part of the same email chain and confirms receipt of the forwarded discovery requests.

In the same exchange, the February 17, 2025 thread shows the initial message from Bryce Koon again, sent to Klapheke and Hornback with the same subject. The message reiterated that Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC were attached along with the associated notice filed that day, and that a Word copy was included for convenience. It again provided the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and carried the same attorney‑client disclaimer, followed by the Dinsmore & Shohl “NOTICE” about privilege and error handling.

On March 19, 2025, at 11:40:38 AM (Eastern Time), Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent another follow‑up email to counsel for the defense. The subject again referenced Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943). The content read: “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to follow up on your client's discovery responses. Any update is appreciated.” The message again included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and carried the same confidential‑privilege disclaimers, as well as the standard disclaimer stating that the email is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged information, with instructions to contact The Whaley Law Firm if received in error and not to waive any privilege by disclosure. The email also contained the same Notice from Dinsmore & Shohl regarding privilege.

Overall, the communications document a February 17, 2025 exchange in which Plaintiff’s discovery requests and a Word copy were forwarded to defense counsel, with confirmations of receipt, followed by a March 19, 2025 follow‑up seeking an update on the defense’s discovery responses.

The file note identifies the client as Jerome Hedinger and records activity dated to February 2025 through March 2025, involving discovery requests and responses between counsel for the plaintiff and defendant.

On February 17, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC, along with the associated notice filed that day. The transmission included a Word copy of the discovery requests for convenience and indicated that counsel was available to address any questions. The email was addressed to Paige E. Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP and to David Klapheke, with cc’s that included Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine project email address and Sarena Tuttle, among others. The message carried the standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of the firm’s communications, including a notice stating that the transmission may constitute an attorney‑client communication protected by law and instructions to delete or notify the sender if received in error.

Paige Hornback replied later on February 17, 2025, acknowledging receipt with a brief, “Bryce, Received. Thanks for forwarding.”

Earlier that same day, Bryce sent the discovery materials with the subject line Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943), informing the recipients that the attached materials included Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC and the associated notice, and that a Word copy was provided for convenience. The email identified the recipients as Klapheke and Hornback, with cc’d parties including Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine address and Sarena Tuttle, and it again included the standard privilege notice.

Also on February 17, 2025, Paige Hornback’s message to Bryce acknowledged receipt of the forwarded materials, indicating they had been received.

Subsequently, on February 17, 2025, Bryce followed up with Paige and David Klapheke, asking for an update on the status of the client’s discovery responses, stating that any update would be appreciated. This follow-up underscored that the plaintiff was awaiting responses to the discovery requests.

On March 19, 2025, Paige Hornback responded to Bryce’s follow-up, noting that they were showing the discovery responses were due today and that they were working on finalizing their responses. She explained that additional information and documents were needed to finalize and serve the responses and asked whether they could have an additional 30 days to respond, which would push the deadline to Friday, April 18, 2025. She thanked Bryce for considering the request and provided her contact details and firm information: Paige E. Hornback, Associate at Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202; telephone 502-540-2594; fax 502-585-2207; email Paige.Hornback@dinsmore.com.

Bryce’s reply to that request was sent later on March 19, 2025, with a concise, courteous note: “Not a worry at all. Thank you for getting back to me – April 18th will be fine.” This response was sent on the same day as Hornback’s extension inquiry and was addressed to Paige Hornback, with David Klapheke and other cc’d recipients still included.

Throughout this email chain, the parties continued to exchange communications related to discovery timing, with the February 17, 2025 transmission formalizing the discovery requests, the mid-February receipt acknowledgment, and the March 19, 2025 extension discussion that ultimately established April 18, 2025, as the prospective new deadline for serving discovery responses, pending agreement.

On February 17, 2025, at approximately 12:56 PM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to David Klapheke and Paige Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP regarding the above matter. The email was CC’d to the Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 Filevine project email address (JeromeHedingerZ4403793@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) and to Sarena Tuttle. The subject line was Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943). In the body of the email, Bryce attached Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC along with the associated notice filed that day, and noted that a Word copy was included for convenience. He invited any questions about the matter. He closed with thanks and his signature, identifying himself as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 237-3207. The email contained the standard attorney-client privilege and confidentiality notice, stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not waive any privilege or forward the information to anyone not intended to receive it.

That same day, February 17, 2025, at around 12:59 PM, Paige E. Hornback, Associate at Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, replied to Bryce. Her response read simply, “Bryce, Received. Thanks for forwarding.” Paige’s signature block followed, identifying her as an Associate at Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, with the firm’s Louisville address at 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202, and contact details including T: (502) 540-2594, F: (502) 585-2207, and E: Paige.Hornback@dinsmore.com. The signature also included a reference to Dinsmore & Shohl’s website, dinsmore.com, and a placeholder image labeled [image: Dinsmore]. The email again carried a confidentiality disclaimer similar to Bryce’s prior message, noting that the electronic transmission may be privileged and should not be used by anyone other than the intended recipient.

In the header of Bryce Koon’s March 19, 2025 email, dated Wednesday, March 19, 2025 at 11:40:38 -0400, Bryce wrote again to counsel involved in the Jefferson case. The To field listed Paige Hornback and David Klapheke, and the CC field again included the Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle. The body of this message read: “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to follow up on your client's discovery responses. Any update is appreciated.” Bryce’s signature block followed, including his Whaley Law Firm information and contact details (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207). The email again included the customary attorney-client privilege and confidentiality notice, stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and that any attachment should not be used or forwarded if received in error, and that no waiver of privilege applies.

The email chain also included, as part of the correspondence, the standard notice from Dinsmore & Shohl regarding the privileged nature of attorney-client communications and the prohibition on transmission to unauthorized persons. Case: Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. in Jefferson County, docket 24-CI-006943. This note chronicles a chain of email communications between counsel regarding plaintiff discovery responses and a request for an extension.

On February 17, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Paige E. Hornback, an associate at Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, and to David Klapheke, also with Dinsmore. The subject was Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943). In the body, Bryce attached Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC, along with the associated notice filed that day, and included a Word copy for convenience. The message also stated that if there were questions, Bryce should be contacted. The email was CC’d to Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 – Filevine Project Email Address (Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine address) and to Sarena Tuttle. It also carried the standard attorney-client disclaimer common to these transmissions, noting that the message may contain privileged information and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or use the information.

Earlier that same day, at 12:56 PM, Bryce had sent the email described above, and at about 12:59 PM Paige Hornback replied with a brief acknowledgment: “Bryce, Received. Thanks for forwarding.” Paige’s reply included her Dinsmore signature block, listing her title as Associate and providing the firm’s Louisville address (101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202), telephone and fax numbers, and her email and website.

On March 19, 2025, at 11:41 AM, Bryce followed up with Paige and David Klapheke, asking for an update on the plaintiff’s discovery responses and indicating that any update would be appreciated.

Later that day, at 16:15:53 UTC, Paige sent a reply to Bryce, noting that discovery responses were due today and that her office was working to finalize responses but required additional information and documents to finalize and serve. Paige requested an extension of 30 days, which would move the deadline to Friday, April 18, 2025, and asked for confirmation that this extension would be agreeable. Paige’s message was again CC’d to Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 – Filevine Project Email Address, Sarena Tuttle, David Klapheke, Elizabeth Harbolt, and Linda Bandy. Paige’s closing included her Dinsmore contact details as listed above.

Throughout the chain, the correspondents included the following participants: Paige E. Hornback (Dinsmore & Shohl LLP), Associate; and Bryce Koon, Esq. (The Whaley Law Firm). The CC recipients included Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine address, Sarena Tuttle, David Klapheke, Elizabeth Harbolt, and Linda Bandy. The emails repeatedly reference discovery, the need for information and documents to complete discovery responses, and a proposed thirty-day extension to the response deadlines.

The transmission bottom notes included standard email-like notices about privileged information and proper use: an attorney-client privilege disclaimer indicating that the electronic transmission may constitute privileged communications, that it is intended only for the named recipient, and instructions for recipients who may have received the email in error to delete it and notify the sender to correct the address record.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger.

In the matter of Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943), counsel communications concerning discovery were exchanged between The Whaley Law Firm and Dinsmore & Shohl LLP. The Whaley Law Firm represented the plaintiff, Jerome Hedinger, with W. Bryce Koon, Esq. acting as lead counsel, whose firm address is 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and who could be reached at (502) 365-5043 (fax: 502-237-3207). Dinsmore & Shohl LLP represented the defendant(s), with Paige E. Hornback, Associate, operating at 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202 (telephone 502-540-2594, fax 502-585-2207). The discovery-related emails contained standard attorney-client privilege and confidentiality notices.

On February 17, 2025, Bryce Koon sent plaintiff’s discovery requests to defendant 432 Atwood, LLC, along with the associated notice filed that day, and attached a Word copy for convenience. He cc’d the Jerome Hedinger Filevine project email address (JeromeHedingerZ4403793@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) and Sarena Tuttle, and included the same generic disclaimer about privilege and intended recipients. The email from Bryce stated that it contained Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC and noted that a notice had been filed that day, with an attached Word copy for convenience. A separate notice paragraph reminded that the transmission could be privileged and should be deleted or reported if received in error.

Later on February 17, 2025, Paige Hornback replied to Bryce: “Bryce, Received. Thanks for forwarding.” This response came from Hornback’s Dinsmore & Shohl email account, which also carried the firm’s standard signature block and the privilege disclaimer. Earlier that same day, Bryce had sent another message to David Klapheke and Paige Hornback with the subject line “Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943).” In that thread, Bryce wrote: “Attached please find Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC along with the associated notice filed today. Included is a Word copy for your convenience. If you have any questions in this regard, please let me know.” He again noted the affiliation with The Whaley Law Firm and provided contact information, along with the customary confidentiality disclaimer.

Earlier still on February 17, 2025, Bryce had written to the opposing counsel (to Klapheke and Hornback) reiterating the same subject and attaching the discovery requests and notice, and a copy was sent to Sarena Tuttle and the Jerome Hedinger Filevine address. That message concluded with the standard attorney-client privilege notice.

On March 19, 2025, the matter progressed with an extension discussion. Bryce sent a follow-up email at 11:41 AM to Paige Hornback and David Klapheke, asking for an update on the defendants’ discovery responses and indicating that any update would be appreciated. On the same day, Paige replied at approximately 12:16 PM, explaining that the defendants’ discovery responses were due to Bryce that day but that they needed additional information and documents to finalize and serve the responses. Paige requested a 30-day extension, stating that it would push the deadline to Friday, April 18, 2025, and asked whether that would be agreeable.

That afternoon, at 12:28:21 PM on March 19, 2025, Bryce replied: “Paige, Not a worry at all. Thank you for getting back to me - April 18th will be fine.” He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the same Louisville address and contact details previously listed, and included the same attorney-client privilege disclaimer. The email chain also carried the firm’s standard “NOTICE: This electronic mail transmission...” disclaimer typical of Dinsmore & Shohl’s communications.

In sum, the parties engaged in a routine discovery exchange for Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, with plaintiff’s counsel issuing discovery requests on February 17, 2025, defendant’s counsel acknowledging receipt, and a March 19, 2025 request by the defense for a 30-day extension to April 18, 2025, which plaintiff’s counsel accepted.

Good morning Jerry,
 Thank you for reaching out. Please update the email address you have on
file, it appears you sent this to an old email that honestly should be
closed at this point. However, Bryce has spoken with the Defense for the
Property Owner, 432 Atwood LLC and we are awaiting their responses to our
Discovery Requests. Currently, they have until April 19th to respond.
Unfortunately, we still have not received an Answer to Complaint from Mr.
Brown and/or Mrs. Burden, though they have been served. We will continue to
move forward into litigation with Defendant 432 Atwood and will consider
Default Judgements on the Brown & Burden at a later date. If we sought the
Default Judgement on them now, it could hinder our claims against 432
Atwood LLC. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to
contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.

Sarena M. Tuttle

The email thread titled “Re: Checking In” was sent on Thursday, March 20, 2025 at 10:47:02 a.m. -0400 from Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm to Jerome Hedinger, with Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon copied on the message.

In that email, Sarena begins by greeting Jerry and thanking him for reaching out. She asks that he update the email address on file, noting that he had sent the message to an old address that should ideally be closed. She then informs him that Bryce has spoken with the defense for the property owner, 432 Atwood LLC, and that they are currently awaiting responses to the firm’s discovery requests; the opposing party has until April 19th to respond.

Sarena also reports that the firm has not yet received an Answer to Complaint from Mr. Brown and/or Mrs. Burden, although those individuals have been served. The plan is to continue with litigation against Defendant 432 Atwood LLC and to consider Default Judgments on Brown and Burden at a later date. She notes that pursuing a Default Judgment against Brown and Burden now could hinder the firm’s claims against 432 Atwood LLC. She invites Jerry to contact the firm directly if he has any further questions to discuss in more detail.

The message is signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971, the office line is (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is her new email address.

For context, an earlier exchange occurred on March 19, 2025, when Jerome Hedinger wrote to Sarena: “Hey Serena, I hope Spring is kicking into gear well. I was wondering if Brice had an update on the dog bite. Is there anything I can get to you all. Jerry Hedinger.”
