Case: Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943). The client is Jerome Hedinger. This matter is documented in the Jerome Hedinger Premise file dated 10-24-2023.

On February 17, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC, along with the associated notice filed that day. The email included a Word copy for the recipient’s convenience and was addressed to David Klapheke and Paige Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, with the Jerome Hedinger Filevine project email address and Sarena Tuttle cc’d. The email contained the standard attorney‑client privilege and confidentiality notice, stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and that any error should be reported to The Whaley Law Firm and not forwarded to others.

Paige Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl responded later that same day, writing, “Bryce Received. Thanks for forwarding,” followed by the same confidentiality notice.

Earlier that day, Bryce had sent the discovery requests with the attached notice and the Word copy, again including the same privilege and confidentiality language. The email thread shows the standard disclosures accompanying the transmission.

On February 17, 2025, in another exchange, Bryce sent an email to Klapheke and Hornback with the subject Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943), cc’ing Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 – Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle. The message concluded with the familiar attorney‑client privilege disclaimer.

By February 17, 2025, Paige Hornback replied to Bryce, noting receipt of the forwarded materials.

Moving to March 19, 2025, at approximately 11:41 AM, Bryce wrote to Paige and David, “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to follow up on your client’s discovery responses. Any update is appreciated,” again using the Whaley Law Firm contact information and including the same confidentially disclaimer.

At about 12:16 PM on March 19, 2025, Paige responded: “Hi Bryce, I hope you’re well. We are showing that our discovery responses are due to you today, and we are working on finalizing our responses. However, we need some additional information and documents to finalize and serve. Could we have an additional 30 days to respond? This would update our deadline to Friday, April 18, 2025. Please let us know if this is agreeable – thanks!” Her signature provides her contact details: Paige E. Hornback, Associate, Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202, T (502) 540-2594, F (502) 585-2207, E Paige.Hornback@dinsmore.com.

Bryce replied later that same day, at about 12:28 PM: “Paige, Not a worry at all. Thank you for getting back to me - April 18th will be fine.” This response, like the prior messages, included the standard attorney‑client privilege disclaimer.

On April 23, 2025, at 11:10:01 AM Eastern Time, Bryce Koon sent a final note: “Good morning Paige, Just circling back on these responses. Any updated appreciated.” This message carried the Whaley Law Firm contact information and the customary confidentiality notice.

Signature details for the parties involved consistently appear in the correspondence. The Whaley Law Firm is listed as the sender for the initial discovery request communications, with its Louisville, Kentucky office at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone (502) 365-5043; fax (502) 237-3207. Dinsmore & Shohl LLP is listed as the recipient’s counsel, with its Louisville, Kentucky office at 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202; phone (502) 540-2594; fax (502) 585-2207; email Paige.Hornback@dinsmore.com. The chain of emails also references Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine project email address (JeromeHedingerZ4403793@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) and includes Sarena Tuttle in cc, among others.

In sum, the correspondence centers on service of Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to the Defendant, discussions of timing for discovery responses, requests for a 30-day extension to Friday, April 18, 2025, and ongoing follow-ups through late March and into April 2025, all within the ongoing Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. matter in Jefferson County. The communications consistently include standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

In the case caption and introductory materials, the parties and counsel are identified. The Whaley Law Firm, represented by W. Bryce Koon, sent multiple communications to Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, where Paige E. Hornback was one of the principal recipients. The email thread includes the following participants: Bryce Koon (The Whaley Law Firm), Paige E. Hornback (Dinsmore & Shohl LLP), David Klapheke (Dinsmore), Sarena Tuttle (Whaley), Elizabeth Harbolt (Dinsmore), and Linda Bandy (Dinsmore). The CC line also includes a Filevine project address for Jerome Hedinger and the client’s file that is labeled Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023. The subject line in the key exchange is Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. (Jefferson 24-CI-006943). The latest dated note in the file is May 1, 2025.

On February 17, 2025, W. Bryce Koon sent an email to Paige Hornback and David Klapheke, with Jerome Hedinger’s Filevine project copied to Sarena Tuttle. The message attached Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC, along with the associated notice filed that day, including a Word copy of the discovery requests for convenience. The message included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer and entailed the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The transmission also carried the Dinsmore notice disclaimers about privileged communications and proper handling if received in error. Paige Hornback responded later that day, replying that she had received the attachment or information forwarded, and acknowledging receipt of Bryce’s message. The exchange included the same typical privilege disclaimer language at the end of the message.

Earlier on February 17, 2025, there is also a record of Bryce following up on discovery responses, indicating a desire for an update. The thread shows Paige’s responsive acknowledgment on the same day, confirming receipt of Bryce’s prior transmission.

On March 19, 2025, Paige Hornback advised Bryce that their discovery responses were due that day and that they were working to finalize them, but they needed additional information and documents to complete and serve the responses. She requested a 30-day extension, which would move the deadline to Friday, April 18, 2025.

Bryce Koon replied that the extension would be acceptable, noting, “April 18th will be fine.” This exchange confirms the agreed extension of time for the responses to be served, with the date set to April 18, 2025.

Subsequently, on April 23, 2025, Bryce sent another follow-up message to Paige Hornback, stating that he was following up again on the outstanding items. The message again included his contact information and the Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality notice.

Finally, on May 1, 2025, Bryce sent another follow-up email to counsel, reiterating that he was following up on these matters. The message again carried the Whaley Law Firm’s signature block and a standard confidentiality/disclaimer notice, consistent with the prior communications. Across these exchanges, the parties circulated discovery requests and related notices, discussed the due date for responses, and negotiated an extension to April 18, 2025. The communications include formal confidentiality and privilege notices typical of the respective law firms and preserve all identified participants and contact details, including firm names, addresses, and telephone and fax numbers.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al. in Jefferson County, 24-CI-006943. Client: Jerome Hedinger. This note documents a series of email exchanges between counsel regarding discovery and a pending motion in the Jerome Hedinger matter, listed in the Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023 file.

The correspondence began with a February 17, 2025 exchange. Paige E. Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP replied to Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm, acknowledging receipt of Bryce’s prior message: “Bryce, Received. Thanks for forwarding.”

On March 19, 2025, the parties continued to discuss discovery and deadlines. At roughly 12:16 PM, Paige Hornback asked Bryce if an additional 30 days could be granted to finalize and serve discovery responses, extending the deadline to Friday, April 18, 2025. She noted that their discovery responses were due that day and requested the extension to complete the necessary information and documents. Bryce Koon followed up later that day, around 11:41 AM, expressing appreciation for the update and indicating that he would welcome the extension if it could accommodate their schedules. In response, Paige’s message, sent shortly after, suggested that the extension to April 18 would be acceptable, and Bryce replied again at approximately 12:28 PM, confirming that April 18 would be fine.

On March 19, 2025, Bryce also advised Paige that the parties were working toward finalizing discovery responses and that he would await their updates. Paige’s prior communication had requested the extension to April 18, 2025, and Bryce indicated that he could proceed on that basis.

The dialogue continued on April 23, 2025, with Bryce writing to Paige to circle back on the discovery responses and to request any available updates. He emphasized the need for current information to move matters forward.

A follow-up on May 1, 2025, showed Bryce again pressing for responses, stating that he was following up on the outstanding items.

On May 13, 2025, the parties’ calendars and filings took a more formal turn. Bryce sent a message at 10:51 AM to Paige and David Klapheke, with Elizabeth Harbolt, Linda Bandy, and the Jerome Hedinger Filevine project address CC’d. He attached a Motion to Compel, noting that it had been filed that day and that it was set for a motion hour two weeks out, on May 26, 2025. Bryce added that if they received the opposing party’s responses before that date, he would be happy to remand the motion. In a contemporaneous message sent later that day at 12:58:51 PM, Bryce informed Paige that the clerk had notified him there would be no motion hour on May 26, 2025, and that the motion would instead be rolled to the following Monday, June 2, 2025. He reiterated the same courtesy details and provided his contact information and firm affiliation.

Paige Hornback replied on the same day, May 13, 2025, expressing appreciation for the courtesy and stating that the opposing side would finalize their responses in advance to avoid needing a courthouse trip. Her signature block indicated she is an Associate with Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, located at 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202, with the firm’s contact information.

For reference, the emails were exchanged among the following participants and addresses: Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207; bryce@whaleylawfirm.com) and Paige E. Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP (101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202; phone 502-540-2594; fax 502-585-2207; paige.hornback@dinsmore.com). The CC line also included Elizabeth Harbolt, Linda Bandy, and David Klapheke, with theJerome Hedinger Filevine project email address JeromeHedingerZ4403793@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and the Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 Filevine project file.

A standard attorney-client email disclaimer accompanied each message, stating that the electronic communications were intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged information; recipients are instructed to contact the sender if received in error and not to disclose or forward the information to unauthorized persons. The memo summarized the above as the ongoing procedural timeline in the Jerome Hedinger v. 432 Atwood matter.

Atwood - Atwood's Discovery Responses.” The message was directed to Paige Hornback and David Klapheke of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, with cc copies to Linda Bandy and Elizabeth Harbolt of Dinsmore, and to the Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 Filevine project email address, JeromeHedingerZ4403793@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, including the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and contact details: phone (502) 365-5043 and fax (502) 237-3207. The email contained a standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information; it instructed the recipient who received the message in error to contact The Whaley Law Firm, advised that no waiver of privilege shall apply, and instructed not to use or forward the information to any third person not intended to receive it. The message also notes that it is part of the Jerome Hedinger file and references the Filevine project email address.

Earlier in the chain, on Monday, June 16, 2025, at approximately 2:05 PM, Paige Hornback of Dinsmore & Shohl LLP wrote to counsel, attaching Atwood’s Responses to Plaintiff’s Interrogatories and Requests for Production of Documents, along with the corresponding document production in this matter. Hornback indicated that the parties had exchanged written discovery and asked for dates for her client’s deposition.

The June 16, 2025 message from Paige Hornback included her signature block identifying her as Associate at Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, with a mailing address at 101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202, and contact details: telephone (502) 540-2594, fax (502) 585-2207, email Paige.Hornback@dinsmore.com, and the firm website dinsmore.com. The June 30, 2025 message from Bryce Koon included his signature block with his name, Esq., firm information, and contact details as noted above.

Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023
Client: Jerome Hedinger

CASE FILE REORGANIZATION COMPLETE: Successfully reorganized all 271 case files using the 8-bucket directory system with standardized naming conventions. Phase 1: Generated file inventory and scrambled 66 .md filenames to eliminate naming bias. Phase 2: Deployed 6 parallel sub-agents to analyze files based purely on content, creating comprehensive reorganization map. Phase 3: Quality review achieved 99.6% accuracy (1 error corrected). Phase 4: Executed 194 file operations. Phase 5: Verified 100% compliance with naming conventions and companion file integrity. Files now organized across 9 buckets: Case Information (16), Client (66), Investigation (24), Medical Records (57 across 8 providers), Insurance (6), Lien (6), Negotiation Settlement (2), Litigation (88), Reports (6). All medical records organized by provider with subdirectories. All litigation files in chronological order. Zero files remaining in root directory. Case ready for efficient discovery, settlement negotiations, and trial preparation. Complete reports saved to Reports/ directory including file inventory, reorganization map, quality review summary, and final completion report.
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jerome-Hedinger-Premise-DB-10-24-2023. Client: Jerome Hedinger. All 271 case files have been reorganized using an eight-bucket directory system with standardized naming conventions. The reorganization proceeded in five phases: Phase 1 generated a file inventory and scrambled 66 Markdown (.md) filenames to eliminate naming bias. Phase 2 deployed six parallel sub-agents to analyze files based purely on content, resulting in a comprehensive reorganization map. Phase 3 achieved a quality-review accuracy of 99.6%, with one error corrected. Phase 4 involved 194 file operations, and Phase 5 verified 100% compliance with naming conventions and companion file integrity.

The files are now organized across nine buckets: Case Information (16), Client (66), Investigation (24), Medical Records (57 across eight providers), Insurance (6), Lien (6), Negotiation Settlement (2), Litigation (88), and Reports (6). All medical records are organized by provider with subdirectories, and all litigation files are in chronological order. There are zero files remaining in the root directory. The case is ready for efficient discovery, settlement negotiations, and trial preparation. Complete reports have been saved to the Reports/ directory, including the file inventory, the reorganization map, the quality review summary, and the final completion report.
